title: Can we include payday loans or installment loans in ch 7. How can we get them to stop calling me and family members.
question: Someone called n left vm saying had a claim against me and to call them back. Then calling to leave the same vm to family members which I do not know how they got their numbers. Also made my parents think I was really in trouble for something I am not sure if something I may have paid already.
answers:
You must include all of your debts, including the debt owed to the payday loan creditor, in your bankruptcy case. You should consult a bankruptcy attorney if you have questions regarding whether or not the payday loan is dischargeable - if the loan was taken out within the last 90 days then there could be a presumption of non-dischargeability. If it was an older payday loan (like most), then the debt is likely dischargeable along with your other unsecured debts.

Regarding the creditor calls - you are protected by the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act and the California Rosenthal Fair Debt Collection Practices Act. It is not clear from the facts whether a violation has occurred. However, many bankruptcy attorneys, once retained, will represent you in the interim for the purposes of creditor contact. You may be able to refer these creditors to your attorney while you prepare your bankruptcy documents. If a creditor is a debt collection who knowingly contacts a represented party for the purposes of collecting a consumer debt, the creditor could be in violation of debt collection law. Certain other harassing acts done to embarrass the debtor are also violations. Consider requesting a free yearly credit report and talking with a consumer debt attorney. Make sure to discuss the facts with them before you file a bankruptcy - any potential cause of action or unliquidated claim must be listed under Schedule B of your bankruptcy petition as an asset.

First, you have the DUTY to list any and all debts in a bankruptcy or else you are committing perjury if you intentionally leave one off. You can only use your (1) brains, (2) your bills, and (3) your credit reports..thats all anyone can do. But, if you do leave some creditor off mistakenly, unless it is a nondischargeable type of debt, it still will be discharged in a ch 7 case! Once you file, the court will send a notice to all creditors and then they know to stop those calls you want stopped. Thus, the sooner the better. If you want, just tell your family members that you are filing bankruptcy if you want to and to ignore any creditor calls. Then, go find an attorney that only practices bankruptcy for a living. Although you really only have 2 goals (to discharge all your debts and to keep all assets you have equity in), there are other issues an attorney must go through in your case to make they do not affect or or what to do about them! You may state in writing to that specific creditor that you are filing bankruptcy shortly and they will receive a notice but that might not stop any calls. Good luck.
Yes you not only can include a payday advance loan but you have to if you file Ch7.

Yes, you can include the debts in a bankruptcy case.

There may be issues regarding violations of the Fair Debt Collection Practice Act. You might want to consult an attorney about your bankruptcy issue and the calls. Unfortunately, dealing with payday lenders -- no one should ever ever use them -- is akin to dealing with loan sharks. The threats they make and the harassment they use are unethical, illegal and upsetting. Unfortunately, it is also difficult to prove (otherwise they would be deterred).

Make sure you have all documentation pertaining to the loan available and consider whether the lender is holding one or more postdated, uncashed checks.

Good luck.

You wrote, "Can we include payday loans or installment loans in ch 7. How can we get them to stop calling me and family members."
Yes, include all such debts.
In Eastern District of MO, where I practice, filing bankruptcy would stop the calls, but CA may treat payday loan bounced checks as a criminal matter--something that rarely happens in MO.
